repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Closes #24166

Added a transform functionality base on `has` that can be set on the metadata files.

If this makes sense I can add docs about it.

comment_data.body:
Instead of doing a search/replace on the raw strings, could introduce a format like `{unix:(foo),win:(bar)}` so that the "transform" is given in the tutor contents. 

For example this line: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/ca825f38732252bfe8d285c15fcf1b3d45f2c119/runtime/tutor/en/vim-01-beginner.tutor#L632

would become:

     1. Type `:!{unix:(ls),win:(dir)}`{vim} to get a listing of your directory.

That should also greatly simplify the `tutor#ApplyTransform()` logic. It would just be a single `:%s` call:

```
if has('win32')
  %s/\C\v\{unix:\(([^)]+)\).*win:\(([^)]+)\)}/\2
else
  %s/\C\v\{unix:\(([^)]+)\).*win:\(([^)]+)\)}/\1
endif

     "784": "Adding 123 to 456 gives you 579.",
     "810": "a) This is the first item.",
     "811": "b) This is the second item."
+  },
+  "transform": {
+    "win32": {
+      "!ls": "!dir",
+      "!rm": "!del"

comment_data.body: @justinmk ugly trick here, any suggestions?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -724,7 +724,7 @@ NOTE: You can also read the output of an external command. For example,
  4. [:r](:r) FILENAME              retrieves disk file FILENAME and puts it
                              below the cursor position.
 
- 5. [:r !dir](:r!)                  reads the output of the dir command and
+ 5. [:r !{unix:(ls),win:(dir)}](:r!){unix:(  ),win:( )}                 reads the output of the {unix:(ls),win:(dir)} command and

comment_data.body:
seems fine, but could also do:

```suggestion
 5. [:r !{unix:(ls ),win:(dir)}](:r!)                   reads the output of the {unix:(ls),win:(dir)} command and
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -724,7 +724,7 @@ NOTE: You can also read the output of an external command. For example,
  4. [:r](:r) FILENAME              retrieves disk file FILENAME and puts it
                              below the cursor position.
 
- 5. [:r !dir](:r!)                  reads the output of the dir command and
+ 5. [:r !{unix:(ls),win:(dir)}](:r!){unix:(  ),win:( )}                 reads the output of the {unix:(ls),win:(dir)} command and

comment_data.body:
or we could drop `()` in the format, so this could be:
```suggestion
 5. {unix:[:r !ls](:r!)   }{win:[:r !dir](:r!)  }                 reads the output of the {unix:(ls),win:(dir)} command and
```

Then the `:%s` needs to be updated.

comment_data.body:
one-time setup goes in a setup()

per-test setup goes in before_each

https://lunarmodules.github.io/busted/
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,25 @@
+local helpers = require('test.functional.helpers')(after_each)
+local command = helpers.command
+local feed = helpers.feed
+local is_os = helpers.is_os
+local skip = helpers.skip
+local eval = helpers.eval
+local eq = helpers.eq
+local clear = helpers.clear
+
+describe(':Tutor', function()
+  clear({ args = { '-u', 'NORC' } })
+  command("Tutor")

comment_data.body: ah non-greedy, good idea :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -220,10 +220,20 @@ function! tutor#TutorCmd(tutor_name)
 
     call tutor#SetupVim()
     exe "edit ".l:to_open
+    call tutor#ApplyTransform()
 endfunction
 
 function! tutor#TutorCmdComplete(lead,line,pos)
     let l:tutors = s:GlobTutorials('*')
     let l:names = uniq(sort(map(l:tutors, 'fnamemodify(v:val, ":t:r")'), 's:Sort'))
     return join(l:names, "\n")
 endfunction
+
+function! tutor#ApplyTransform()
+    if has('win32')        
+        sil! %s/{unix:(\(.\{-}\)),win:(\(.\{-}\))}/\2/g
+    else
+        sil! %s/{unix:(\(.\{-}\)),win:(\(.\{-}\))}/\1/g

comment_data.body:
just make this one test with a `if` check.

a screen test is probably better, and adds a ton of coverage with a single test.  See [test/functional/example_spec.lua](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/test/functional/example_spec.lua) for example. You can [run the test](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/test/README.md#running-tests) like this:

    TEST_FILE=test/functional/plugin/tutor_spec.lua make functionaltest
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,25 @@
+local helpers = require('test.functional.helpers')(after_each)
+local command = helpers.command
+local feed = helpers.feed
+local is_os = helpers.is_os
+local skip = helpers.skip
+local eval = helpers.eval
+local eq = helpers.eq
+local clear = helpers.clear
+
+describe(':Tutor', function()
+  clear({ args = { '-u', 'NORC' } })
+  command("Tutor")
+
+  it('should apply transformation for Unix', function()
+    skip(is_os('win'), 'not on Unix')
+    feed("/!ls<CR>")
+    eq(true, eval('line(".")') > 1)
+  end)
+
+  it('should apply transformation for Windows', function()
+    skip(not is_os('win'), 'not on Windows')
+    feed("/!dir<CR>")
+    eq(true, eval('line(".")') > 1)
+  end)

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  before_each(function()
    clear({ args = { '-u', 'NORC' } })
    command('set cmdheight=0')
    command('Tutor')
  end)
```

comment_data.body:
Test seems a bit slow (300ms) but I guess `:Tutor` is kinda slow.

```
-------- Running tests from test/functional/plugin/tutor_spec.lua
RUN      T3855 :Tutor should apply transformation: 231.00 ms OK
-------- 1 test from test/functional/plugin/tutor_spec.lua (382.00 ms total)
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,64 @@
+local Screen = require('test.functional.ui.screen')
+local helpers = require('test.functional.helpers')(after_each)
+local clear = helpers.clear
+local command = helpers.command
+local feed = helpers.feed
+local is_os = helpers.is_os
+
+describe(':Tutor', function()
+  before_each(function()
+    clear({ args = { '-u', 'NORC' } })
+    command('set cmdheight=0')
+    command('Tutor')
+  end)
+
+  it('should apply transformation', function()
+    local test_table = is_os('win') and {
+      ['!dir'] = {
+        '{2:  } 1. Type :{1:^!}{3:dir} to get a listing of your directory.                            |',
+        '{2:  }    To verify this, type :{1:^!}{3:dir} again to see your directory.                   |',
+        '{2:  } 5. Neovim will write the selected lines to the file TEST. Use :{1:^!}{3:dir} to see it|',
+        '{2:  }        :r {1:^!}{3:dir}                                                               |',
+        '{2:  }     :{1:^!}{3:dir}                   - shows a directory listing                      |',
+        '{2:  } 5. {4::r }{5:^!dir}                  reads the output of the dir command and          |',
+        '{2:  } 1. List the contents of the current directory: :{1:^!}{3:dir}                         |'
+      },
+      ['!del'] = {
+        '{2:  }        :{1:^!}{3:del} TEST                                                            |',
+        '{2:  }     :{1:^!}{3:del} FILENAME          - removes file FILENAME                          |',
+      }
+    } or {
+      ['!ls'] = {
+        '{2:  } 1. Type :{1:^!}{3:ls} to get a listing of your directory.                             |',
+        '{2:  }    To verify this, type :{1:^!}{3:ls} again to see your directory.                    |',
+        '{2:  } 5. Neovim will write the selected lines to the file TEST. Use :{1:^!}{3:ls} to see it.|',
+        '{2:  }        :r {1:^!}{3:ls}                                                                |',
+        '{2:  }     :{1:^!}{3:ls}                    - shows a directory listing                      |',
+        '{2:  } 5. {4::r }{5:^!ls}                   reads the output of the ls command and           |',
+        '{2:  } 1. List the contents of the current directory: :{1:^!}{3:ls}                          |'
+      },
+      ['!rm'] = {
+        '{2:  }        :{1:^!}{3:rm} TEST                                                             |',
+        '{2:  }     :{1:^!}{3:rm}  FILENAME          - removes file FILENAME                          |',
+      }
+    }
+
+    local screen = Screen.new(80, 1)
+    screen:set_default_attr_ids({
+      [1] = { foreground = Screen.colors.Brown, bold = true, background = Screen.colors.Yellow1 },
+      [2] = { foreground = Screen.colors.DarkBlue, background = Screen.colors.Gray },
+      [3] = { background = Screen.colors.Yellow },
+      [4] = { underline = true, foreground = tonumber('0x0088ff') },
+      [5] = { underline = true, foreground = tonumber('0x0088ff'), background = Screen.colors.Yellow },
+    })
+    screen:attach()
+
+    for search_word, search_matches in pairs(test_table) do
+      feed('gg0<CR>')
+      for _, expected_line in ipairs(search_matches) do
+        feed('/' .. search_word .. '<CR>')
+        screen:expect(expected_line)
+      end
+    end

comment_data.body: why call expect() on each line instead of one expect() call that gives the full screen? That might be slowing down the test.

comment_data.body: why is it searching for each case? isn't the transformed result visible without the cursor being on the result?
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body: Is there a way to show how long `before_each` took? then we can distinguish if the slow down is on the `:Tutor` or loop expects.

+        '{2:  } 5. Neovim will write the selected lines to the file TEST. Use :{1:^!}{3:dir} to see it|',
+        '{2:  }        :r {1:^!}{3:dir}                                                               |',
+        '{2:  }     :{1:^!}{3:dir}                   - shows a directory listing                      |',
+        '{2:  } 5. {4::r }{5:^!dir}                  reads the output of the dir command and          |',
+        '{2:  } 1. List the contents of the current directory: :{1:^!}{3:dir}                         |'
+      },
+      ['!del'] = {
+        '{2:  }        :{1:^!}{3:del} TEST                                                            |',
+        '{2:  }     :{1:^!}{3:del} FILENAME          - removes file FILENAME                          |',
+      }
+    } or {
+      ['!ls'] = {
+        '{2:  } 1. Type :{1:^!}{3:ls} to get a listing of your directory.                             |',
+        '{2:  }    To verify this, type :{1:^!}{3:ls} again to see your directory.                    |',
+        '{2:  } 5. Neovim will write the selected lines to the file TEST. Use :{1:^!}{3:ls} to see it.|',
+        '{2:  }        :r {1:^!}{3:ls}                                                                |',
+        '{2:  }     :{1:^!}{3:ls}                    - shows a directory listing                      |',
+        '{2:  } 5. {4::r }{5:^!ls}                   reads the output of the ls command and           |',
+        '{2:  } 1. List the contents of the current directory: :{1:^!}{3:ls}                          |'
+      },
+      ['!rm'] = {
+        '{2:  }        :{1:^!}{3:rm} TEST                                                             |',
+        '{2:  }     :{1:^!}{3:rm}  FILENAME          - removes file FILENAME                          |',
+      }
+    }
+
+    local screen = Screen.new(80, 1)
+    screen:set_default_attr_ids({
+      [1] = { foreground = Screen.colors.Brown, bold = true, background = Screen.colors.Yellow1 },
+      [2] = { foreground = Screen.colors.DarkBlue, background = Screen.colors.Gray },
+      [3] = { background = Screen.colors.Yellow },
+      [4] = { underline = true, foreground = tonumber('0x0088ff') },
+      [5] = { underline = true, foreground = tonumber('0x0088ff'), background = Screen.colors.Yellow },
+    })
+    screen:attach()
+
+    for search_word, search_matches in pairs(test_table) do
+      feed('gg0<CR>')
+      for _, expected_line in ipairs(search_matches) do
+        feed('/' .. search_word .. '<CR>')
+        screen:expect(expected_line)

comment_data.body: The first instance of the replace is on line 632 and the last is on line 931, if we can have a screen that long we could do just one check, but if the contents in between those lines changes the test should be updated, even if the change is not related to the transformation itself.

comment_data.body:
> if we can have a screen that long we could do just one check

The screen dimensions are up to the test author:

    local screen = Screen.new(80, 100)


> but if the contents in between those lines changes the test should be updated, even if the change is not related to the transformation itself.

That's fine.

comment_regular_data.body:
This would need a test since it's non-obvious. The test should check actual tutorial contents.

Alternatively we could:

- change the tutorial to mention "on Windows, use ..." in various places.
- or setup 'shell' to use powershell, which I think has both `ls` and `rm`
That was just an idea. I can change the tutorial to mention the Windows version and change the "expect" metadata line numbers if that is better future maintenance.

> That was just an idea. I can change the tutorial to mention the Windows version and change the "expect" metadata line numbers if that is better future maintenance.

I think this way is probably most usable for users, but think we should keep the data in the tutor definition file (see my suggestion above) rather than separately in a "transform" structure. That also makes the content more "self-documenting", even though the syntax is a bit much.

I did as suggested, but some tricks were necessary to maintain the indentation.

I'll work on the tests next.
